choices.text: rk 39 antigen test, Leishmaniasis
pLDH, Plasmodium malaria
Biopsy, Histoplasmosis
ELISA, HIV

questions.text: A man with FUO has a job that requires traveling around the world. The bone marrow picture is shown below. Which of the following investigation would be the most appropriate in this case? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) rk 39 antigen test, Leishmaniasis

 

This given clinical picture shows A and B. macrophage infested with intracellular Leishmania donovani bodies (arrows) characterized by a kinetoplast and characteristic double dot appearance (Leishman stain) suggestive of Leishmaniasis which can be confirmed by the rk 39 antigen test.

 

There are 3 main forms of leishmaniases: visceral (the most serious form because it is almost always fatal without treatment), cutaneous (the most common, usually causing skin ulcers), and mucocutaneous (affecting mouth, nose and throat).

 

Leishmaniasis is caused by protozoan parasites which are transmitted by the bite of infected female phlebotomine sandflies.

 

Following the discovery of a 39-amino acid residue (k-39) encoded by a kinesin-related gene in the amastigotes of Leishmania chagasi, it has been used in the format of enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA). 

 

Immunochromatographic test (ICT) for detection of antibodies with high sensitivity and specificity.1,4–6 Anti-k39 antibodies are secreted into various body fluids such as urine and sputum along with blood, and have been shown to be useful in the diagnosis of Visceral leishmaniasis (VL). rK39 strip test is rapid and a sensitive and specific indicator of visceral leishmaniasis(VL).

 

Parasitological methods of diagnosis remain the gold standard for diagnosing leishmaniasis. Diagnosis in the laboratory can be achieved by direct examination of amastigotes in giemsa-stained lesion smears of scrapping, biopsies, or impression smears.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. pLDH, Plasmodium malaria: Plasmodium malaria would present differently on a blood smear and would not typically show macrophages with intracellular organisms in a bone marrow sample. The pLDH test is specific for diagnosing malaria, not leishmaniasis.

 

Option C. Biopsy, Histoplasmosis: Histoplasmosis could cause fever of unknown origin and show organisms in macrophages, but the morphology would be different from Leishmania donovani. Histoplasma typically appears as small yeast forms within macrophages, not the double dot appearance seen here.

 

Option D. ELISA, HIV: While HIV can present with fever of unknown origin, it would not directly explain the bone marrow findings of intracellular Leishmania bodies. An ELISA test for HIV is not relevant to diagnosing the cause of the observed bone marrow pathology.

 

Educational Objective

 

The presence of macrophages with intracellular Leishmania donovani bodies in the bone marrow is diagnostic for leishmaniasis. The rk 39 antigen test is a rapid and reliable method for confirming visceral leishmaniasis.

questions.text: The maximum oxygen flow rate which can be kept with a conventional Hudson oxygen mask is?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 10 L/min

 

Explanation:

 

The maximum oxygen flow rate which can be kept with a conventional oxygen mask (Simple Face Mask, also known as Hudson mask) is 10 L/min. This is a standard setting for delivering oxygen to patients who require moderate levels of oxygen supplementation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 5 L/min: While 5 L/min can be used, it is not the maximum flow rate for a Hudson mask.

 

Option B. 15 L/min: This flow rate is generally used with a non-rebreather mask rather than a conventional Hudson mask.

 

Option D. 20 L/min: This flow rate exceeds the capacity of most conventional oxygen delivery systems like the Hudson mask.

 

Educational Objective :

 

The maximum flow rate for a conventional Hudson oxygen mask is 10 L/min.

questions.text: Entry of glucose is insulin independent in all of them except: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Answer: C. Adipose tissues

 

Glucose enters cells through GLUT (glucose transporter) proteins. Some are insulin-dependent, while others are not.

 

Adipose tissues:
•    Use GLUT4
•    Insulin-dependent
•    Insulin stimulates translocation of GLUT4 to membrane → increases glucose uptake

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. RBC (Red Blood Cells)
•    Use GLUT1
•    Insulin-independent

 

Option B. Pancreas (β-cells)
•    Use GLUT2
•    Insulin-independent
•    Glucose entry triggers insulin secretion

 

Option D. Brain
•    Uses GLUT1 (BBB) and GLUT3 (neurons)
•    Both are insulin-independent
•    Brain requires a constant glucose supply regardless of insulin


 

Educational Objective:

 

Major Glucose transporters and their function is summarized as:

questions.text: In the case of an elderly male presenting with meningitis, a gram stain of the CSF sample shows the presence of gram-positive bacilli. Which of the following statements accurately pertains to the motility of the responsible microorganism? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Motile at 25° C, non-motile at 37°C

 

  • The provided case involves an elderly man with meningitis, and the smear analysis indicates the presence of a gram-positive bacillus, strongly indicative of a Listeria infection. Listeria exhibits motility at 25°C but loses its ability to move at 37°C.

 

LAB DIAGNOSIS OF LISTERIA MONOCYTOGENES

 

  • Motility: shows differential motility, which is due to temperature dependent flagella expression) 
    • Tumbling type of motility at 25°C
    • Non-Motile at 37°C
  • Culture → Blood agar, Chocolate agar
  • Selective media → PALCAM agar

 

TREATMENT

 

  • Meningitis → DOC → Ampicillin in combination with gentamicin for synergistic effect
  • Penicillin allergy → Cotrimoxazole
  • In febrile gastroenteritis → Amoxicillin

 

Educational Objective:

 

Listeria monocytogenes exhibits motility at 25°C but is non-motile at 37°C.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions do you see punched-out lesions of the retina? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Toxoplasmosis

 

Toxoplasmosis is a parasitic infection caused by Toxoplasma gondii that affects the central nervous system and retina in humans.

 

It can occur as 3 forms:

 

  1. Congenital: infants are typically born with inactive disease, and doctors may observe healed punched-out chorioretinal lesions in the macular region.
  2. Acquired: can also result in similar punched-out lesions, along with punctate outer retinal toxoplasmosis.
  3. Recurrent Toxoplasmosis: Patients may experience multiple episodes of retinal inflammation, leading to further accumulation of these punched-out lesions over time.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Posterior staphyloma: This refers to an outpouching or deformation of the posterior shell of the eye, often associated with severe myopia but not characterized by punched-out lesions.

 

Option B. Fundal coloboma: A congenital malformation resulting in missing pieces of tissue in structures forming the eye, such as the choroid and retina, which does not typically present as punched-out lesions.

 

Option C. Congenital rubella: While it can cause retinal changes, the signature features often include salt and pepper retinopathy rather than punched-out lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The appearance of punched-out lesions in the retina is crucial for diagnosing toxoplasmosis. This understanding can aid in distinguishing toxoplasmosis from other infectious or congenital conditions that affect the retina, guiding appropriate diagnostic and therapeutic interventions.

choices.text: Collagen is a type of fibrous protein, which is most abundant of all human proteins
Post translational hydroxylation of proline & lysine
Triple helix is required for its function

questions.text: Which of the following is false about collagen: (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Most abundant AA is Phenyl-alanine

 

Collagen is a fibrous protein that is indeed the most abundant protein in the human body. It provides structural support to various tissues, including skin, bones, tendons, and blood vessels. However, the most abundant amino acid in collagen is actually glycine, not phenylalanine. Glycine makes up approximately one-third of the amino acids in the collagen protein chain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Collagen is a type of fibrous protein that is the most abundant protein in the human body. It forms a strong and flexible structure in various tissues.

 

Option C. Post-translational hydroxylation of proline and lysine residues is an essential process in collagen synthesis. This hydroxylation is necessary for the proper formation and stability of collagen's triple helix structure.

 

Option D. The triple helix structure is a characteristic feature of collagen and is crucial for its function. Collagen molecules are composed of three polypeptide chains, coiled around each other in a triple helical arrangement. This structure provides collagen with its strength and stability.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognizing the correct composition of collagen is essential to understand its structural role in the human body.

questions.text: A patient who is a known case of angle-closure glaucoma has been diagnosed with major depressive disorder. Which of the following drugs have to be avoided in this patient? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Amitriptyline

 

  • Amitriptyline is a tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) that is known to have marked anticholinergic activity.
  • TCAs have high affinity for muscarinic acetylcholine (M type) receptors, causing the subsequent blockade of these receptors.
  • Blocking of these receptors can result in decreased outflow of aqueous humour, leading to an increase in intraocular pressure.
  • This effect can exacerbate pre-existing angle-closure type glaucoma, which is already characterized by impaired drainage of aqueous humour.
  • Therefore, amitriptyline is a drug to be avoided in patients with angle-closure glaucoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Options B and D: Sertraline and Fluvoxamine are selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors with no activity at the muscarinic cholinergic receptors and therefore have no effect on the outflow of aqueous humor and thereby, on the intraocular pressure.

 

Option C: Mirtazapine is an atypical antidepressant that is a serotonin-norephedrine reuptake inhibitor with the ability to precipitate angle-closure glaucoma by itself; however, due to lack of any activity at the muscarinic cholinergic receptors, it does not increase the intraocular pressure to the extent that Amitriptyline does.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with angle-closure glaucoma, medications with anticholinergic properties, such as Amitriptyline, should be avoided due to their potential to increase intraocular pressure and exacerbate the condition.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements accurately describe the operation and management of Mobile Medical Units (MMUs)? [INICET MAY 2021]

 

  1. MMUs are run by the government
  2. MMUs are run by external agencies with medical supplies given by the government.
  3. MMUs are run by the government and medical supplies are also given by the government.
  4. MMUs are run by external agencies and medical supplies are also given by the external agency.
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) 1, 2, and 3

 

  • MMUs can be operated by either the Government or an external agency; however, the availability of drugs and medical supplies is exclusively the responsibility of the Government.
  • Mobile Medical Units (MMU) represents a significant project within NRHM, aimed at delivering a variety of healthcare services to individuals residing in distant, hard-to-reach, unserved, and underserved regions, encompassing both rural and urban locations.
  • The goal is to bring essential healthcare services directly to the residents in these areas.

 

There are 3 models of operationalizing MMUs:

 

  1. Government operated MMU
  2. MMU operation is outsourced to an external agency, while the government covers capital expenses, medication, and supplies.
  3. External agency outsourcing includes both capital and operational expenses for MMUs.

 

The government is responsible for providing medication and supplies. MMUs offer essential primary healthcare services for prevalent illnesses (both communicable and non-communicable), reproductive and child health (RCH) services, screening examinations, and necessary referrals to advanced facilities and specialists. Medical Officer-led clinical services are delivered by a team, while mobilization and outreach activities are undertaken by ANMs and ASHA personnel.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Services and Resources of MMUs:

 

  • MMUs offer a variety of services, including primary care for common diseases, reproductive and child health services, diagnostic screenings, and referrals to specialized care.
  • They are equipped with facilities for basic diagnostic tests such as blood glucose monitoring, pregnancy testing, and sputum sample collection, among others.
  • Human resources typically include a medical officer, a nurse, a lab technician, a pharmacist/administrative assistant, and a driver/support staff.

questions.text: The rupture of penile urethra does not cause extravasation of blood into which of the following spaces? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Deep perineal pouch

 

Option B. Deep perineal pouch: This is a space situated superior to the perineal membrane and inferior to the pelvic diaphragm. It contains the membranous urethra, deep transverse perineal muscles, and parts of the external urethral sphincter. Extravasation of urine is possible in deep perineal pouch.

 

When there is a rupture of the penile urethra (often due to trauma, such as a straddle injury), the extravasation of urine and blood can occur into various anatomical spaces, depending on the location and nature of the injury.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superficial perineal pouch: This is a space located in the urogenital triangle of the perineum, bounded above by the perineal membrane and below by the perineal (Colles') fascia. The pouch contains the root of the penis (including the bulb of the penis) and the associated muscles. A rupture of the penile urethra can cause extravasation of urine and blood into this space.

 

Option C. Skin around penis. The skin around base of penis may get involved if the rupture is located in the bulbous part of urethra.

 

Option D. Skin around the scrotum: With a rupture of the penile urethra, especially if the rupture occurs in the bulbous part located within the superficial perineal pouch, the extravasated urine and blood can dissect through the fascial layers and present as swelling and bruising around the scrotum and base of the penis. This is often referred to as a "butterfly" pattern of bruising, as the extravasated fluid can spread anteriorly onto the anterior abdominal wall and laterally to the thighs but is typically limited superiorly by Scarpa's fascia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rupture of the penile urethra causes extravasation of blood into the superficial perineal pouch, scrotum, penis, and then up to the lower anterior abdominal wall.

 

The membranous layer of superficial fascia attaches to the ischiopubic rami and forms the lateral borders of the urogenital triangle. Thus, the urine does not extravasate to the thigh.

choices.text: Dark ground microscopy

questions.text: A pregnant female visited the obstetrics and gynecology outpatient department (OBG OPD) for her regular prenatal examination. Her past pregnancy involved a stillbirth at 28 weeks. She has a history of engaging in sexual relations with multiple partners and recalls a painless sore on her vulva before her previous pregnancy. What initial investigative step should be taken for this patient? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) VDRL

 

The given scenario with a pregnant female has a history of stillbirth and painless genital ulcer is suggestive of Syphilis. So, Venereal disease research laboratory test (VDRL test) will be the first investigation to be done.

 

SYPHILIS IN PREGNANCY

 

  • Caused by Treponema pallidum
  • Primary Syphilis – Characterized by painless, nontender, single papule over the genitalia, that rapidly becomes eroded and usually becomes indurated, and is called a hard chancre.
  • Kassowitz Law – gradually improving fetal outcomes in congenital syphilis
  • Screening test – VDRL (done for all antenatal patients; May be false positive)
  • USG: FGR, hepatomegaly, fetal anemia, hydrops, placentomegaly
  • Treatment – Benzathine penicillin 2.4 million U

 

Other options:

 

Option A. HIV ELISA: HIV ELISA is done routinely for screening antenatal patients.

 

Option C. Dark ground microscopy: Dark ground microscopy is done when an active ulcer is present.

 

Option D. Culture: Treponema pallidum can’t be cultured. It is not the preferred method to diagnose or screen syphilis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a pregnant woman with a history of stillbirth and a painless genital ulcer, the initial investigation should be the VDRL test to screen for syphilis, as syphilis can significantly impact pregnancy outcomes and requires prompt treatment.

questions.text: Which Biochemical method is exploited for monoclonal antibody production by hybridoma technique?  (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Purine salvage pathway

 

Hybridoma technology → common methods used to produce monoclonal antibodies

 

In this process, antibody-producing B-lymphocytes are isolated from mice after immunizing the mice with specific antigen and are fused with immortal myeloma cell lines to form hybrid cells, called hybridoma cell lines.

 

 

  • Even the most efficient fusion method will give only 1 to 2% of fused and viable hybridoma cells.
  • Hybridoma selection involve screening of the fused cells from the unfused cells. It is done using HAT media (a selection media).
  • HAT medium contains Hypoxanthine-Aminopterin-Thymidine. The trick is that Aminopterin inhibits DHFR. So, it inhibits de-novo purine synthesis. Inhibition of DHFR also inhibits conversion of dUMP to dTMP.
  • Salvage pathway will occur, but only in B-cells, not myeloma cells. Myeloma cells are deficient in HGPRT .
  • Hypoxanthine and deoxythymidine allow cells with functional hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT) genes to survive through salvage pathways.
  • Due to a limited life span, unfused B cells perish within a few days.
  • Unfused malignant neoplastic cells die as a result of the lack of HGPRT gene
  • Therefore, the remaining viable cells left in the media are the hybrid cells; these hybrid cells have the ability to grow and divide on HAT media because they have functional HGPRT gene from B lymphocytes

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glycolytic pathway: This pathway is involved in the breakdown of glucose to pyruvate for energy production and is not specifically exploited in hybridoma technology for monoclonal antibody production.

 

Option B. Pentose Phosphate pathway: This pathway generates NADPH and ribose-5-phosphate for nucleotide synthesis but is not the key pathway exploited in the hybridoma technique.

 

Option C. Kreb’s cycle: This cycle is part of cellular respiration and energy production but is not directly involved in the selection process of hybridoma cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The purine salvage pathway is critical in hybridoma technology for monoclonal antibody production, enabling the selection of viable hybridoma cells in HAT medium.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presented with recurrent URTI, poor growth, high-arched palate, and impaired hearing. Tympanogram is given as follows. What would be the most appropriate management?(INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adenoidectomy with grommet insertion 

 

The presentation of a child with a type B tympanometry curve indicates the likelihood of serous otitis media due to adenoid hypertrophy as the underlying cause.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Grommet insertion: While this can relieve middle ear effusion, it does not address the underlying adenoid hypertrophy.

 

Option C. Myringotomy with grommet insertion: Similar to grommet insertion alone, this option does not address the root cause of adenoid hypertrophy.

 

Option D. Myringotomy: This procedure involves making an incision in the tympanic membrane to relieve pressure or drain fluid but does not address the cause or provide a lasting solution like adenoidectomy with grommet insertion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adenoidectomy with grommet insertion is the most appropriate management for a child presenting with serous otitis media due to adenoid hypertrophy, addressing both the immediate symptoms and underlying cause.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents with lesion in tibial diaphysis. Histopathological examination is shown in below given image. On IHC, it was MIC-2 positive and synaptophysin positive cells. Most likely diagnosis will be: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ewing sarcoma

 

EWING SARCOMA

 

  • Ewing sarcoma is the fourth most common primary malignancy of bone, but it is the second most common (after osteosarcoma) in patients younger than 30 years of age and the most common in patients younger than 10 years of age. 

  • Its maximum incidence is seen in 2nd decade of life.

  • Ewing sarcoma more often originates in the metaphysis of a long bone, but frequently extends for a considerable distance into the diaphysis. 

  • Diagnosis:

    • Laboratory studies may reveal an increased white blood cell count, an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and an elevated C-reactive protein.

    • A needle aspirate may grossly resemble pus.

    • Classically, Ewing sarcoma appears radiographically as a destructive lesion in the diaphysis of a long bone with an “onion skin” periosteal reaction. 

 

 

  • The image provided in the question shows a tumor composed of numerous small, relatively uniform, round, blue cells with scant cytoplasm. This is the classic "small round blue cell tumor" appearance, which is typical of Ewing sarcoma.

 

  • Markers/Cytogenetics:

  • Ewing's sarcoma is part of a family of peripheral neuroectodermal tumors (PNET) that share a common cytogenetic translocation of chromosomes 11 and 22, t(11:22).

  • MIC2 (CD99) is a specific marker for Ewing's sarcoma and is expressed on short-arm of chromosome x and y. This is a highly characteristic and almost universally positive marker for Ewing sarcoma. It is often used as the primary diagnostic marker.

  • Synaptophysin is more commonly associated with neuroendocrine tumors, but it can be focally positive in some Ewing sarcomas, reflecting its neuroectodermal origin. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Malignant neuroblastoma. Neuroblastoma (NB) is the most frequently-occurring extracranial childhood tumor. It is classified as an embryonal neuroendocrine tumor, originating from neural crest progenitor cells. Hence, it can occur anywhere along the sympathetic nervous system, including the superior cervical, paraspinal, and celiac ganglia; the majority arise in the adrenal glands. The most important biological marker is MYCN. Patients with the MYCN gene tend to have rapid progression of cancer and poor outcomes. Other biological markers linked to poor prognosis include lack of expression of glycoprotein CD 44, elevated levels of telomerase RNA, elevated levels of LDH, serum ferritin, and serum neuron-specific enolase. 90% patients have elevations in vanillyl mandelic acid and homovanillic acid in the urine. Histopathology reveal small, round, blue cells known as Homer-Wright pseudorosettes (in 10-15% cases), with clustering of cells in the connective tissue. 

 

 

Small, round, blue cells known as Homer-Wright pseudorosettes

 

Option C. Osteosarcoma. Osteosarcoma is a tumor characterized by the production of osteoid matrix by malignant cells. It is the second most common primary malignancy of bone behind multiple myeloma. Onset can occur at any age; however, primary high-grade osteosarcoma occurs most commonly in the second decade of life. All skeletal locations can be affected; however, most primary osteosarcomas occur at the sites of the most rapid bone growth, including the distal femur, the proximal tibia, and the proximal humerus. Periosteal reaction may take the form of “Codman’s triangle”, or it may have a “sunburst” or “hair on end” appearance. Histologically, osteoid production from the tumor cells is seen, presenting as calcification. 

 

 

Codman’s triangle 

 

Option D. Osteoclastoma. They typically occur in patients 20-40 years old, and there is a slight female predominance. The most common location for this tumor is the distal femur, followed closely by the proximal tibia. Tumor of lower end radius is GCT till proved otherwise. Microscopically, giant cell tumors are composed of many multinucleated giant cells (typically 40-60 nuclei per cell) in a sea of mononuclear stromal cells (malignant cells). The nuclei of the mononuclear cells are identical to the nuclei of the giant cells, a feature that helps to distinguish giant cell tumors from other tumors that may contain many giant cells.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The combination of the patient's age, the diaphyseal location of the bone lesion, the classic small round blue cell morphology on histology, and especially the strong MIC-2 (CD99) positivity with some synaptophysin positivity, makes Ewing sarcoma the definitive and most appropriate diagnosis.

choices.text: High homocysteine and normal methylmalonic acid
Hemolytic anemia is a feature
B12 supplementation is recommended along with Folate
Purine and pyrimidine synthesis are affected

questions.text: In folate deficiency, the False statement is: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hemolytic anemia is a feature

 

Folate deficiency primarily leads to megaloblastic anemia, which is characterized by large, immature red blood cells (macrocytes) in the bone marrow and blood due to impaired DNA synthesis. Folate is crucial for the synthesis of purines and pyrimidines, the building blocks of DNA, which is why DNA synthesis is directly affected.

 

  • High homocysteine and normal methylmalonic acid: In folate deficiency, homocysteine levels increase because folate is required for the remethylation of homocysteine to methionine. However, methylmalonic acid levels remain normal, which helps differentiate folate deficiency from vitamin B12 deficiency, where methylmalonic acid levels are elevated.
  • B12 supplementation is recommended along with Folate: This is recommended because both vitamin B12 and folate deficiencies can lead to similar hematologic manifestations, like megaloblastic anemia. However, treating a patient with folic acid alone when they have an undiagnosed vitamin B12 deficiency can mask the hematologic symptoms while allowing neurological damage to progress. Therefore, it is safer to supplement both B12 and folate unless B12 deficiency has been ruled out.
  • Purine and pyrimidine synthesis are affected: Folate is essential for the synthesis of purines and pyrimidines, which are necessary for DNA replication. Specifically, folate is involved in the transfer of one-carbon units during the synthesis of these nucleotides. In its absence, DNA synthesis is impaired, leading to megaloblastic anemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. High homocysteine and normal methylmalonic acid: This statement is true and correctly describes the biochemical changes in folate deficiency.

 

Option C. B12 supplementation is recommended along with Folate: This is a true statement and an important clinical practice to avoid masking B12 deficiency.

 

Option D. Purine and pyrimidine synthesis are affected: This statement is true because folate is directly involved in nucleotide synthesis, which is critical for DNA replication and repair.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Folate deficiency leads to megaloblastic anemia, not hemolytic anemia. It is associated with high homocysteine levels and normal methylmalonic acid levels, and folate is essential for purine and pyrimidine synthesis, which are necessary for DNA synthesis

questions.text: Which skull foramen is formed by 3 bones?(INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Foramen lacerum

 

Explanation:

 

The foramen lacerum is a triangular-shaped foramen located in the skull base. It is largely filled with cartilage in a living individual and serves as a landmark rather than a conduit for significant neurovascular structures (though some smaller emissary veins and nerves might pass through). Importantly, the internal carotid artery courses superiorly to this foramen but doesn't pass through it. The foramen lacerum is bordered by three bones:

 

  • Petrous part of the temporal bone: This bone forms the posterior and medial aspect of the foramen lacerum.
  • Sphenoid bone: The greater wing of the sphenoid bone forms the anterior and lateral aspect of the foramen lacerum.
  • Basilar part of the occipital bone: The basilar part of the occipital bone forms the posterior and medial aspect of the foramen lacerum.

 

The foramen lacerum is covered by a fibrous membrane, which makes it difficult to see and access.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Foramen magnum: The foramen magnum is the largest foramen of the skull and is located in its base. Through it pass the medulla oblongata (which becomes the spinal cord as it exits the skull), the vertebral arteries, spinal parts of the accessory nerves, and the anterior and posterior spinal arteries. It is formed entirely by the occipital bone.

 

Option C. Foramen rotundum: The foramen rotundum is located in the greater wing of the sphenoid bone. Through this foramen, the maxillary branch of the trigeminal nerve (V2) exits the cranial cavity to enter the pterygopalatine fossa. It is formed solely by the sphenoid bone.

 

Option D. Foramen jugulare (jugular foramen): The jugular foramen is a large irregular opening located between the petrous part of the temporal bone and the occipital bone. This foramen transmits the internal jugular vein and several cranial nerves: the glossopharyngeal (IX), vagus (X), and accessory (XI) nerves. It is formed by two bones:

 

  1. Anterolaterally: the petrous part of the temporal bone.
  2. Posteromedially: the occipital bone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The foramen lacerum's formation by three bones (the petrous part of the temporal bone, greater wing of the sphenoid bone, and basilar part of the occipital bone) makes it unique among the foramina at the base of the skull. Understanding its anatomical context and relations is crucial for interpreting imaging and planning surgeries involving the cranial base.

questions.text:
Arrange in sequence the structures involved in the direct pathway: (INICET NOV 2022)

 

1. Striatum

2. Globus pallidus

3. Substantia nigra

4. Thalamus

5. Cortex
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 5,1,2,3,4

 

Explanation:

 

The correct sequence is as follows:

 

5. Cortex - provides the initial input to the basal ganglia.

 

1. Striatum - receives input from the cortex and is the first structure in the basal ganglia circuitry.

 

2. Globus pallidus - receives inhibitory input from the striatum and projects to the thalamus.

 

3. Substantia nigra - provides dopaminergic input to the striatum.

 

4. Thalamus - receives excitatory input from the globus pallidus and projects back to the cortex to complete the loop.

 

The basal ganglia needs the input from the cortex in order to act. The first and last component of the pathway is always the cerebral cortex. 


The complete pathway is Cortex/ Thalamus/ brain stem to stratum, then to globus pallidus & substantia nigra then to thalamus and then back to cortex.


Hence out of the available options 5,1,2,3,4 is the best suitable.

 

 

 

The putamen is located laterally and the internal capsule is located medially to the pallidum. The striatum and subthalamic nuclei send fibres to it. It is the primary basal ganglia output to the thalamus and superior colliculus. Each cerebral peduncle of the midbrain located deep to the crus cerebri contains the substantia nigra. Dopamine levels in the substantia nigra and striata are reduced in Parkinson's disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct order of structures in the direct pathway of the basal ganglia starts with the cortex and follows through the striatum, globus pallidus, substantia nigra, and ends at the thalamus. This pathway is fundamental in processing motor signals, which is particularly relevant in understanding disorders like Parkinson’s disease.

questions.text: After parotidectomy, lower lip paralysis was seen in a patient. Which of the following part of facial nerve was involved ? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cervical branch of facial nerve

 

The cervical branch of the facial nerve is responsible for innervating the platysma muscle, which is crucial for controlling lower lip movements. During a parotidectomy, if this branch is damaged, it can lead to paralysis of the lower lip.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Parotid duct: The parotid duct is not a part of the facial nerve. It is a salivary duct and does not contribute to nerve innervation.

 

Option B. Temporal branch of facial nerve: The temporal branch of the facial nerve innervates the muscles of the forehead, including the frontalis, corrugator supercilii, and orbicularis oculi. It does not affect lower lip movements.

 

Option D. Main trunk of facial nerve: The main trunk of the facial nerve divides into several branches, including the temporal and cervical branches. It is not directly responsible for the lower lip movement, as it provides the general innervation before splitting into specific branches.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Damage to the cervical branch of the facial nerve during a parotidectomy can result in lower lip paralysis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of Kawasaki disease?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Purulent conjunctivitis


Kawasaki disease is a medium vessel vasculitis that typically affects children and involves several characteristic features. The mnemonic "REEMA" helps remember these features:

 

  • R for Rash: Patients with Kawasaki disease often have a polymorphous rash.
  • E for Edema: Edema of the hands and feet is common in Kawasaki disease.
  • E for Eyes: Patients have non-purulent conjunctivitis, which is a hallmark of the disease.
  • M for Mucosal involvement: Mucosal changes include a strawberry tongue and cracked lips.
  • A for Adenopathy: Cervical lymphadenopathy is a typical feature.
  • Patients also exhibit prolonged fever lasting more than five days.
  • Thrombocytosis (increased platelet count) is another feature of Kawasaki disease during the subacute phase.

 

Purulent conjunctivitis, which involves a discharge of pus, is not a feature of Kawasaki disease. Instead, patients typically have non-purulent conjunctivitis.

 

Educational Objective:


Non-purulent conjunctivitis is a feature of Kawasaki disease, whereas purulent conjunctivitis is not.

questions.text: How long should elective surgery be deferred for a patient who had cough and fever, after he has recovered from COVID-19, and has not required any hospitalization?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 6 weeks

 

Elective surgery deferral based on respiratory disease severity and COVID-19 recovery:

 

  • 4 weeks: For an asymptomatic patient with mild respiratory symptoms.
  • 6 weeks: For a symptomatic patient who did not need hospital treatment.
  • 8 weeks: For a symptomatic patient who was hospitalized in the ward.
  • 12 weeks: For a patient who was admitted to the intensive care unit due to respiratory infection.

 

Application:

 

  • As this patient was symptomatic but did not need hospitalization, elective surgery can be deferred for 6 weeks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 8-10 weeks: This timeline is recommended for symptomatic patients who were hospitalized in the ward, which does not apply to this patient.

 

Option C. 12 weeks: This timeline is for patients who were admitted to the intensive care unit due to a respiratory infection, which also does not apply to this patient.

 

Option D. 4 weeks: This timeline is for asymptomatic patients with mild respiratory symptoms, which is not the case for this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Elective surgery should be deferred for 6 weeks in a patient who had cough and fever due to COVID-19 but did not require hospitalization. This ensures sufficient recovery time to reduce perioperative risks.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 2423

questions.text: A young patient undergoing treatment for multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB) presents with symptoms of weight gain, cold intolerance, and lethargy. Laboratory investigations reveal high levels of thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) and low levels of T3 (triiodothyronine) and T4 (thyroxine). Which of the following drugs is likely responsible for these symptoms? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ethionamide.

 

Ethionamide, a second-line antitubercular agent used in the treatment of MDR-TB, is known to cause hypothyroidism as a side effect. This condition is characterized by an underactive thyroid gland, leading to symptoms such as weight gain, cold intolerance, and lethargy. The laboratory findings of elevated TSH and low levels of T3 and T4 further support this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cycloserine: Cycloserine is used in the treatment of MDR-TB, but its side effects are more commonly neurological, including mood changes and seizures. It is not typically associated with thyroid dysfunction.

 

Option C. Streptomycin: Streptomycin, an aminoglycoside antibiotic, is used in TB treatment and is known for its potential ototoxicity and nephrotoxicity, rather than effects on thyroid function.

 

Option D. Pyrazinamide: Pyrazinamide is a first-line anti-TB medication. Its side effects include hepatotoxicity and hyperuricemia but not typically hypothyroidism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ethionamide, a second-line drug used in the treatment of multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB), can cause hypothyroidism, characterized by symptoms such as weight gain, cold intolerance, lethargy, elevated TSH, and low T3 and T4 levels.

questions.text: A female patient presents to the AIIMS emergency department with severe fatigue and prostration. She is a known case of chronic stable angina. While collecting a blood sample, you notice the blood has a brownish hue. What is the underlying diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans.  C) Methemoglobinemia

 

The patient presenting with a brownish hue in the blood, coupled with a history of chronic stable angina, points towards methemoglobinemia. Patients with chronic stable angina are often on nitrate therapy, which is a known risk factor for developing methemoglobinemia.

 

Methemoglobinemia occurs when the iron in hemoglobin is oxidized from the ferrous (Fe²⁺) state to the ferric (Fe³⁺) state, which is unable to bind oxygen effectively. This results in reduced oxygen delivery to tissues, leading to symptoms such as fatigue and cyanosis. The brownish hue of the blood, often described as chocolate-colored, is characteristic of methemoglobinemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carboxyhemoglobinemia: Carboxyhemoglobinemia is caused by carbon monoxide poisoning, typically associated with exposure to fire or automobile exhaust. The blood in this condition has a cherry red color, not brownish.

 

Option B. Sideroblastic anemia: Sideroblastic anemia is a form of anemia where the bone marrow produces ringed sideroblasts rather than healthy red blood cells. It does not cause a brownish hue in the blood.

 

Option D. Sulfhemoglobinemia: Sulfhemoglobinemia results from the incorporation of sulfur into hemoglobin, leading to a greenish or bluish color of the blood, rather than brownish.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A brownish hue in the blood, especially in a patient on nitrate therapy, is indicative of methemoglobinemia, a condition where hemoglobin is oxidized, impairing its ability to carry oxygen effectively.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a major diagnostic criterion of neuromyelitis Optica? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Focal epilepsy

 

Neuromyelitis optica (NMO) spectrum disorder, also known as Devic's disease, is an autoimmune condition characterized by severe, recurrent episodes of optic neuritis and myelitis. The diagnostic criteria for NMO spectrum disorders include specific clinical syndromes.  

 

Focal epilepsy is not a diagnostic criterion for NMO. While seizures can occur in NMOSD due to brain lesions, focal epilepsy itself is not a major diagnostic feature.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Area postrema syndrome  is major criteria. This is characterized by intractable nausea, vomiting, or hiccups, which is due to lesions in the area postrema of the brainstem.

 

Option B. Acute myelitis is major criteria. Inflammation of the spinal cord, usually longitudinally extensive (spanning three or more vertebral segments).

 

Option D. Optic neuritis is major criteria. This involves inflammation of the optic nerve, leading to vision loss or impairment, often affecting both eyes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diagnostic Criteria for Neuromyelitis Optica Spectrum Disorder (NMOSD)

 

Most Common Core Clinical criteria:

 

  1. Longitudinal extensive transverse myelitis (acute myelitis)
  2. Optic neuritis, often bilateral
  3. Area postrema syndrome

 

Less Common Clinical Criteria:

 

  1. Acute brainstem syndrome
  2. Acute diencephalic syndrome, which can manifest as symptomatic narcolepsy
  3. Symptomatic cerebral syndrome (symptomatic cerebral lesions)

 

Some patients with NMOSD may have anti-NMO IgG antibody positivity, also known as anti-aquaporin 4 antibody (AQP4-IgG).

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with history of acute MI complains of acute, severe, and diffuse abdominal pain accompanied by multiple episodes of vomiting. Upon examination, his pulse rate is 110bpm with an irregular rhythm, while his blood pressure is 100/70 mmHg. The abdomen looks soft, not swollen, and there are no bowel sounds. What potential diagnosis could be considered for this patient based on these findings? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acute mesenteric ischemia (AMI)

 

AMI refers to the sudden onset of intestinal hypoperfusion, which can be caused by an arterial embolism, arterial thrombosis, or venous thrombosis. Given the patient's history of ischemic heart disease (IHD), he is at risk for cardiac emboli. The symptoms described, such as severe diffuse abdominal pain out of proportion to the clinical findings with an absence of bowel sounds and vomiting, are typical for AMI. The irregular rhythm (possibly atrial fibrillation) increases the risk of embolization, leading to acute mesenteric ischemia, typically involving SMA leading to massive intestinal gangrene if not treated promptly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute severe pancreatitis: While this can cause severe abdominal pain, it typically presents with pain radiating to the back and is often associated with a history of alcohol intake or gallstone disease. The absence of bowel sounds might be seen, but other signs like fever, lack of increased amylase or lipase levels, and the nature of pain differentiate it from AMI.

 

Option B. Ruptured aortic aneurysm: This is a life-threatening condition that presents with sudden, severe pain. While it can cause hypotension, the nature of pain and other clinical findings (e.g., palpable pulsatile abdominal mass) can differentiate it from AMI.

 

Option D. Peptic ulcer perforation: A perforated peptic ulcer can lead to sudden, severe abdominal pain. However, this typically presents with a board-like rigid abdomen due to the spillage of gastric contents into the peritoneal cavity, leading to acute peritonitis. This is different from the "soft" abdomen described in the scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The given clinical scenario suggests acute mesenteric ischemia as a possible diagnosis. The most common cause of acute mesenteric ischemia is an embolus. The risk factors for acute mesenteric ischemia/embolus in the given clinical scenario are the presence of an irregularly irregular pulse suggestive of atrial fibrillation and a previous history of ischemic heart disease/myocardial infarction.

 

The sudden onset of severe abdominal pain in a patient with atrial fibrillation or atherosclerosis is the most important clue to an early diagnosis of acute mesenteric ischemia. The pain is typically in the central abdomen and out of proportion to the physical findings. Associated features may include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal distension, peritonitis, and passage of bloody stools.

 

Angiography is the gold standard for the diagnosis of acute mesenteric ischemia, and management involves laparotomy. The goal of operative exploration is to reset the compromised bowel and restore blood supply via embolectomy.

choices.text: TDM is done with penicillin because of narrow therapeutic index
TDM is done with gentamicin because of narrow therapeutic index
TDM is done with both because of dangerous side effects
Both drugs do not need monitoring

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct for a patient on high dose of penicillin and gentamicin? iNICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. TDM is done with gentamicin because of narrow therapeutic index


Therapeutic Drug Monitoring has to be done for drugs that have a narrow safety margin. Gentamicin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic that acts by inhibiting the protein synthesis at the 30S ribosomal subunit of the bacteria. It is nephrotoxic as well as ototoxic. It has a narrow therapeutic margin; therefore, it requires TDM.

 

Option B. TDM is done with gentamicin because of narrow therapeutic index: Gentamicin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic, and these drugs are known for their narrow therapeutic index. TDM is important for gentamicin to ensure effective therapeutic levels are achieved without causing toxicity. Aminoglycosides can cause nephrotoxicity (kidney damage) and ototoxicity (hearing loss), so monitoring blood levels is crucial to avoid these adverse effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. TDM is done with penicillin because of narrow therapeutic index: This is not typically the case. Penicillin, for the most part, does not have a narrow therapeutic index, and Therapeutic Drug Monitoring (TDM) is generally not required for penicillin.

 

Options C. TDM is done with both because of dangerous side effects: While it's true that both drugs can have side effects, TDM is generally only recommended for gentamicin because of its narrow therapeutic window and potential for serious side effects. Penicillin does not typically require TDM.

 

Options D. Both drugs do not need monitoring: This statement is incorrect because gentamicin does require monitoring due to its narrow therapeutic index and potential for toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Therapeutic Drug Monitoring (TDM) is crucial for gentamicin due to its narrow therapeutic index and potential for nephrotoxicity and ototoxicity. Penicillin, on the other hand, generally does not require TDM because it does not have a narrow therapeutic index.

questions.text: In a patient with renal stones, the following crystals suggest what etiology? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Triple phosphate

 

The image provided in the question shows crystals that are described as "coffin-lid" shaped. These crystals are characteristic of triple phosphate stones, also known as struvite stones. Struvite stones are commonly associated with urinary tract infections caused by urease-producing bacteria, which raise the urine pH and promote the formation of these crystals.

 

  • Triple Phosphate Crystals (Struvite): These crystals have a distinctive coffin-lid shape, which is clearly depicted in the image. They are typically seen in alkaline urine and are associated with infections, especially those caused by urease-producing organisms like Proteus, Klebsiella, or Pseudomonas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Uric Acid: Uric acid crystals are usually rhomboid or rosette-shaped. They form in acidic urine and are not associated with the coffin-lid appearance shown in the image.

 

Option C. Calcium Oxalate Monohydrate: These crystals have a dumbbell or ovoid shape, not resembling the coffin-lid appearance in the image.

 

Option D. Calcium Oxalate Dihydrate: These crystals are typically envelope-shaped, resembling a square with a diagonal cross. While they might be confused with the coffin-lid shape, they are distinctively different.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coffin-lid shaped crystals in a urine analysis are indicative of triple phosphate stones, commonly associated with urinary tract infections and alkaline urine.

questions.text: The graph below shows oxygen dissociation curves. What does the curve marked as red indicate?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Myoglobin

 

The curve 'A' shows a hyperbolic curve that is characteristic of oxygen dissociation in myoglobin.

 

 

The red curve in the graph indicates the oxygen dissociation curve for myoglobin. This curve is hyperbolic, which is characteristic of myoglobin's oxygen binding properties.

 

Myoglobin: Myoglobin can bind only one oxygen molecule and does not exhibit cooperative binding like hemoglobin. This results in a hyperbolic oxygen dissociation curve, which means myoglobin has a very high affinity for oxygen and releases it only at low partial pressures of oxygen (PO2). This high affinity allows myoglobin to effectively store oxygen in muscle tissues and release it during periods of low oxygen availability.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Carboxyhemoglobin: The dissociation curve for carboxyhemoglobin would show a leftward shift and a reduced maximal oxygen carrying capacity due to carbon monoxide binding with high affinity to hemoglobin, but it would not have the hyperbolic shape seen with myoglobin.

 

Option C. Methemoglobin: Methemoglobin has an oxidized form of iron that cannot bind oxygen effectively. The curve would show a decreased oxygen carrying capacity but would not match the hyperbolic shape of the myoglobin curve.

 

Option D. Fetal Hemoglobin (HbF): Fetal hemoglobin has a higher affinity for oxygen compared to adult hemoglobin, resulting in a leftward shift of the oxygen dissociation curve. However, it still exhibits cooperative binding, unlike myoglobin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The oxygen dissociation curve for myoglobin is hyperbolic, indicating its high affinity for oxygen and its role in oxygen storage within muscle tissues. This curve differs from the sigmoidal curve of hemoglobin, which exhibits cooperative binding.

questions.text: Identify the pathology from the given flow-volume loop: (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fixed central airway obstruction


The flow-volume loop shows flattening of both the inspiratory and expiratory limbs, which is characteristic of a fixed central airway obstruction. This pattern suggests an obstruction that affects airflow both during inhalation and exhalation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fixed distal airway obstruction would not typically affect both phases of the loop.

 

Option C. Variable intrathoracic obstruction affects the expiratory phase more.

 

Option D. Variable extrathoracic obstruction affects the inspiratory phase more.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Flattening of both inspiratory and expiratory limbs in a flow-volume loop indicates a fixed central airway obstruction.

choices.text: Intact cell organelle
Altered cell shape
Enzyme mediated degradation
Internal organelle disintegration with lipid change

questions.text: Which of the following is not helpful for differentiating between necrosis and apoptosis?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Altered cell shape

 

Necrosis and apoptosis are two distinct types of cell death, each with its own characteristics.

 

Altered cell shape: While cell shape can change in both necrosis and apoptosis, it is not a reliable indicator to differentiate between the two. The more useful parameter is cell size: in necrosis, cells swell, whereas in apoptosis, cells shrink. Therefore, altered cell shape is not particularly helpful in distinguishing necrosis from apoptosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intact cell organelle: During apoptosis, cell organelles remain intact until the late stages when apoptotic bodies form. These bodies contain tightly packed cytoplasmic components and organelles. In contrast, necrosis is characterized by the breakdown and disintegration of organelles. Thus, the presence of intact organelles helps differentiate apoptosis from necrosis.

 

Option C. Enzyme mediated degradation: This is a hallmark of necrosis. In necrosis, enzymes digest cellular components, leading to the breakdown of organelles and other structures. This feature is not seen in apoptosis, where cellular components are typically preserved until the cell is packaged into apoptotic bodies.

 

Option D. Internal organelle disintegration with lipid change: Necrosis involves the disintegration of organelles and changes in lipids, leading to the loss of cell membrane integrity. This is not a feature of apoptosis, where the membrane remains intact until late stages.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The key features to differentiate necrosis from apoptosis include the state of cell organelles (intact in apoptosis, disintegrated in necrosis), enzyme-mediated degradation (present in necrosis), and internal organelle disintegration with lipid changes (present in necrosis). Altered cell shape alone is not a useful parameter for differentiation.

questions.text: All of the following conditions are caused by high-risk strains of Human Papilloma virus except: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Laryngeal papillomatosis

 

 

Laryngeal papillomatosis is not caused by high-risk HPV strains but by low-risk HPV strains (6 and 11).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cervical carcinoma: Caused by high-risk HPV strains, particularly HPV 16 and 18.

 

Option B. Anal carcinoma: Also associated with high-risk HPV strains, including HPV 16.

 

Option C. Oropharyngeal carcinoma: Linked to high-risk HPV strains, notably HPV 16.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laryngeal papillomatosis is caused by low-risk HPV strains (6 and 11) and not by the high-risk strains associated with cancers such as cervical, anal, and oropharyngeal carcinoma.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 563

choices.text: It is the meeting point of frontal, parietal, temporal and sphenoid bones.
Blow to the lateral side of the skull injures the marked structure.
Accessory middle meningeal artery lies under this structure.
It corresponds to site of anterolateral fontanelle of fetal skull.

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement regarding the marked structure: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Accessory middle meningeal artery lies under this structure.

 

Explanation:

 

The structure marked in the image is the pterion. The main branch of Middle meningeal artery lies under this structure NOT accessory middle meningeal artery. The accessory middle meningeal artery usually arises from the maxillary artery and enters the middle cranial fossa through the foramen ovale or a separate foramen. Its location and presence can vary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is the meeting point of frontal, parietal, temporal, and sphenoid bones. Correct: The pterion is indeed the meeting point of these four bones.

 

Option B. Blow to the lateral side of the skull injures the marked structure. Correct: A blow to the pterion can be very dangerous because the middle meningeal artery runs just deep to this area, on the inner side of the skull. If this artery is ruptured due to a fracture at the pterion, it can lead to an epidural hematoma, which is a type of traumatic brain injury.

 

Option D. It corresponds to the site of the anterolateral fontanelle of the fetal skull. Correct: The pterion corresponds to the region of the anterolateral (or sphenoid) fontanelle in the fetal skull. This fontanelle usually closes a few months after birth.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pterion is the junction point of four bones in the skull: the frontal, parietal, temporal, and sphenoid bones. The term "pterion" comes from the Greek word "pteron," meaning "wing," because the pterion is located at the point where the sphenoid bone and the temporal bone form a wing-like shape. The pterion is located just above the zygomatic arch and anterior to the ear. The middle meningeal artery, a branch of the maxillary artery, runs underneath the pterion and is at risk of injury in cases of head trauma.

questions.text: A patient presents to the casualty following blunt trauma to the chest. A chest X-ray was done. Among the following radiographs, in which case would you further evaluate the patient before putting a chest tube? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3,4

 

Explanation:

 

  1. Pneumothorax
  2. Hemothorax
  3. Consolidation
  4. Diaphragmatic hernia

 

Image 3: Consolidation would be managed symptomatically and chest tube shouldn’t be inserted.

 

Image 4: Diaphragmatic hernia: A direct blow to the diaphragm can cause it to rupture, allowing abdominal contents to herniate into the chest. In the case of stomach herniation into the chest, a nasogastric tube followed by chest radiography can be helpful. Video-assisted thoracoscopy or laparoscopy is the most accurate investigation.

 

Other Options:

 

Radiographs 1-2 show hemothorax and pneumothorax. Intercostal chest drains should be inserted into the fifth intercostal space. The safe landmark is a triangle anterior to the midaxillary line above the nipple, below, and lateral to the pectoralis major muscle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of blunt chest trauma, careful evaluation of chest radiographs is crucial. Consolidations (Image 3) and diaphragmatic hernias (Image 4) require specific management strategies distinct from those of pneumothorax or hemothorax, where immediate chest tube placement is standard.

choices.text: Cry of baby in the womb
Infection of vagina
Infection of uterus
Infection of both vagina and uterus

questions.text: What is vagitus uterinus? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cry of baby in the womb

 

  • Vagitus uterinus is the term used to describe the cry of a baby in the womb. It is a rare phenomenon but can occur if there is a rupture of the amniotic sac with air entry, allowing the baby to make crying sounds while still in utero.
  • Vagitus vaginus is the term for the cry of the baby in the vagina, which can be heard during delivery.
  • Infection of the vagina causes vaginitis.
  • Infection of the uterus may affect its layers, leading to conditions such as endometritis (infection of the endometrium), myometritis (infection of the myometrium), and perimetritis (infection of the perimetrium).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Infection of vagina: Infection of the vagina causes vaginitis, which is not related to the term vagitus uterinus.

 

Option C. Infection of uterus: Infection of the uterus can lead to endometritis, myometritis, or perimetritis, which are not related to the term vagitus uterinus.

 

Option D. Infection of both vagina and uterus: Infection of both the vagina and uterus involves conditions such as vaginitis and endometritis/myometritis/perimetritis, which are not related to the term vagitus uterinus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vagitus uterinus refers to the cry of a baby in the womb, which is a rare phenomenon that can occur if there is a rupture of the amniotic sac with air entry.

questions.text: What is the content of given vacutainer? (AIIMS MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Clot activator

 

The plastic tube shown in the given image has a red stopper, hence it contains clot activator

 

Red stopper plastic tubes contain silica as a clot activator.

 

The tubes are inverted five times to initiate the clotting process.

 

Use – Serum Analysis, Serology tests, Blood banks

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Na-EDTA: EDTA is an anticoagulant used in tubes with a lavender stopper for hematological tests such as complete blood counts (CBC).

 

Option B. Trisodium citrate: This anticoagulant is used in light blue stopper tubes, primarily for coagulation studies such as PT and APTT.

 

Option C. Na-heparin: Heparin is an anticoagulant used in tubes with a green stopper, commonly for plasma biochemistry tests.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which gene defect causes familial hyperlipidemia? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) LDLr

 

Familial hyperlipidemia, particularly familial hypercholesterolemia (FH), is a genetic disorder characterized by high levels of low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol in the blood. The primary cause of this condition is mutations in the LDL receptor (LDLr) gene.

 

Mechanism of Action: The LDL receptor is responsible for the uptake of LDL cholesterol from the blood into the liver. When there are mutations in the LDLr gene, the receptors are either dysfunctional or deficient. As a result, LDL cholesterol cannot be effectively removed from the bloodstream, leading to elevated levels of LDL cholesterol. This condition significantly increases the risk of atherosclerosis and cardiovascular diseases.

 

  • Heterozygous FH: This form is more common and results in moderately high LDL cholesterol levels (200-300 mg/dL). It is associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular diseases.
  • Homozygous FH: This form is rarer and more severe, with LDL cholesterol levels potentially reaching 600-700 mg/dL. Individuals with homozygous FH have a very high risk of early cardiovascular events and death.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ApoE:  Mutations in the ApoE gene cause familial dysbetalipoproteinemia (Type III hyperlipoproteinemia in Frederickson classification), which leads to elevated levels of intermediate-density lipoproteins (IDL) and is characterized by the presence of remnant particles in the blood.

 

Option B. ApoCII:  Deficiency in ApoCII causes familial chylomicronemia syndrome (Type I hyperlipoproteinemia in Frederickson classification). This condition is associated with extremely high levels of triglycerides due to impaired lipoprotein lipase (LPL) activation, which is necessary for the breakdown of triglycerides.

 

Option D. ApoB48:  ApoB48 is involved in the assembly and secretion of chylomicrons from the intestine. There is no known condition caused by a deficiency of ApoB48 that leads to familial hyperlipidemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mutations in the LDL receptor (LDLr) gene cause familial hypercholesterolemia, a condition characterized by high levels of LDL cholesterol in the blood due to impaired clearance by the liver. This condition significantly increases the risk of cardiovascular diseases.

questions.text: A patient came to be emergency department with a radiograph showing posterior dislocation of hip. No associated fractures are seen. What is the next step in management? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Closed reduction

 

POSTERIOR DISLOCATION OF THE HIP

 

  • The head of the femur is pushed out of the acetabulum posteriorly. 
  • It is more common (90%)
  • Mechanism of injury:
    • The injury is sustained by violence directed along the shaft of the femur, with the hip flexed.
    • The occupant of the car is thrown forwards and his knee strikes against the dashboard. 
    • The axial load applied on a flexed knee placed in adduction.
    • The force is transmitted up the femoral shaft, resulting in posterior dislocation of the hip. It is, therefore, also known as dashboard injury.

 

 

  • Clinical features: 
    • The patient presents with a history of severe trauma followed by pain, swelling and deformity (flexion, adduction and internal rotation – FADIR), associated with a shortening of the leg.

 

 

  • Radiological features: 
    • The femoral head is out of the acetabulum. 

 

 

  • The thigh is internally rotated so that the lesser trochanter is not seen. Shenton’s line is broken.

 

  • Treatment:
    • In most cases, it is possible to reduce the hip by closed manipulation under general anaesthesia. 
    • Closed reduction is the primary and most urgent step in the management of an acute traumatic hip dislocation without associated contraindications. 
    • The sooner the reduction, the lower the risk of complications like AVN. 
    • Open reduction may be required in cases where:
      • Closed reduction fails, usually in those presenting late
      • If there is intra-articular loose fragment not allowing accurate reduction
      • If the acetabular fragment is large and is from the weight-bearing part of the acetabulum. Such a fragment makes the hip unstable.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Open reduction. Open reduction is done when closed reduction fails, usually in patients presenting late OR if there is an intra-articular loose fragment not allowing accurate reduction OR if the acetabular fragment is large and is from the weight bearing part of the acetabulum. Since the question states "No associated fractures are seen," and it's an acute presentation, open reduction is not the first line.

 

Option C. NCCT pelvis: A CT scan is very useful after closed reduction to check for concentric reduction, identify any occult fractures not seen on plain X-rays (especially small intra-articular fragments or acetabular wall fractures), and assess for incarceration of fragments. However, it is not the immediate next step before reduction in an uncomplicated dislocation, as delaying reduction to get a CT increases the risk of AVN. The priority is to reduce the hip.

 

Option D. Arthroplasty. Hip replacement surgery can be considered if optimal stability is not achieved with reduction and fixation of the associated injuries. It is a definitive surgical procedure, usually performed for severe arthritis or irreparable damage. It is definitely not the immediate next step for an acute hip dislocation in a patient who likely has no pre-existing severe joint disease and no associated fractures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The treatment of choice for posterior dislocations of hip is closed reduction/manipulation under general anesthesia in cases with no associated fractures.

questions.text: You're a clinician in a busy urban sexual health clinic, and it's been a hectic day with multiple patients presenting with sexually transmitted infections (STIs). The STI treatment kits are color-coded for efficient management, but the new nurse seems a bit overwhelmed with the options. You decide to guide her. Based on the clinical presentation, which color-coded STI kit would you suggest for the following symptoms? [INICET MAY 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) A-4, B-1, C-3, D-2

 

A. Lower abdominal pain:

 

  • Correct Kit: Yellow, Kit 6, which includes Cefixime, Metronidazole, and Doxycycline, specifically designed to manage symptoms like lower abdominal pain, which can be associated with pelvic inflammatory disease or other related conditions.

 

B. Urethral discharge:

 

  • Correct Kit: Grey, Kit 1, which contains Azithromycin and Cefixime. This kit is ideal for treating symptoms like urethral discharge, which can indicate infections such as gonorrhea or chlamydia.

 

C. Non-herpetic genital ulcer:

 

  • Correct Kit: White, Kit 3, equipped with Azithromycin and Penicillin, suitable for treating non-herpetic genital ulcers, often caused by syphilis or chancroid.

 

D. Vaginal discharge:

 

  • Correct Kit: Green, Kit 2, which contains Secnidazole and Fluconazole, tailored for treating vaginal discharge that could be due to bacterial vaginosis or yeast infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The National Aids Control Organization (NACO has provided color-coded kits for the syndromic management of sexually transmitted diseases:

questions.text:
Which of the following findings are typically associated with glomerular hematuria? (INICET NOV 2024)

 

  1. Brown urine
  2. Dysuria absent
  3. Crystals in urine
  4. Edema is rare
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A, B

 

Glomerular hematuria has specific characteristics that help differentiate it from non-glomerular causes:

 

A. Brown urine: Brown/cola-colored urine is typical of glomerular hematuria due to the presence of RBCs.

 

B. Dysuria absent: Absence of dysuria is characteristic, as there is no urinary tract inflammation or infection.

 

These findings together strongly suggest glomerular origin of hematuria.

 

Other Options:

 

C. Crystals in urine: Incorrect. Crystalluria is not a feature of glomerular hematuria. Instead, findings like dysmorphic RBCs, acanthocytes, or RBC casts are characteristic.

 

D. Edema is rare: Incorrect. Edema is common in glomerular diseases, whether nephritic or nephrotic, due to:

 

  • Loss of albumin leading to decreased oncotic pressure
  • Activation of the renin-angiotensin system
  • Underlying inflammatory processes

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glomerular hematuria includes brown/cola-colored urine and absence of dysuria, while presence of edema and absence of urinary crystals are other important characteristics.

questions.text: Which of the following groups is not considered a core risk factor group for HIV transmission? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Long-distance truck drivers

 

The core risk groups for HIV transmission are populations that primarily transmit the disease to bridge populations, who then transmit it to the general population. In endemic countries like India, addressing these core groups is crucial for reducing HIV transmission rates. The core high-risk groups include female sex workers, men who have sex with men (MSM), transgender populations, and injectable drug users.

 

Long-distance truck drivers are considered a bridge population rather than a core risk group. While they are important in the transmission chain, they act as intermediaries between core risk groups and the general population.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Female sex workers: Incorrect. This is a core risk group according to NACO 2024 data and is one of the primary populations targeted for HIV prevention.

 

Option C. Male having sex with male (MSM): Incorrect. MSM is a core high-risk group that requires focused intervention for HIV prevention.

 

Option D. IV drug abusers: Incorrect. Injectable drug users are considered a core high-risk group for HIV transmission.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The distinction between core risk groups and bridge populations in HIV transmission:

 

Core risk groups include:

 

  1. Female sex workers
  2. Men who have sex with men (MSM)
  3. Transgender populations
  4. Injectable drug users

 

Bridge populations, like truck drivers and migrants, serve as intermediaries in disease transmission.

questions.text: A child presented with bilateral proptosis. From the peripheral smear, he was suspected to have chloroma. What is the next investigation of choice? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bone marrow examination

 

The next investigation of choice, in a child suspected to have a chloroma, is a bone marrow biopsy.

 

Chloroma or granulocytic sarcoma is an extramedullary manifestation that occurs in 2% to 14% of patients with acute myeloid leukemia (AML). It is a localised tumour forming mass occurring in the skin or orbit due to local infiltration of the tissues by leukemic cells. The tumour is greenish in appearance due to the presence of myeloperoxidase.

 

Frequent sites of involvement are the skin, lymph nodes, gastrointestinal tract, bone, soft tissue, testis, and peritoneum. Isolated orbital involvement of myeloid sarcoma is rare. Proptosis is the most common presentation. Other symptoms include lacrimal swelling, conjunctival mass lesion, retinal hemorrhages, ptosis, dystopia. Decreased visual acuity and ocular movement restriction have also been reported.

 

The diagnosis of AML is made by a combination of routine blood picture and bone marrow examination, coupled with cytochemical stains and other special laboratory investigations.

 

The diagnosis of AML is based on the presence of at least 20% myeloid blasts in the bone marrow.

 

Although myeloid sarcomas are radiosensitive, they are managed with systemic chemotherapy in most cases, even in the absence of bone marrow involvement. Surgery and/or radiation therapy may be indicated for symptomatic lesions or tumors causing local organ dysfunction or obstruction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Platelet count: While important in assessing overall hematologic status, platelet count alone is not sufficient to diagnose chloroma or AML.

 

Option B. WBC count: Similarly, WBC count is part of the complete blood count but does not provide the definitive diagnosis needed in this case.

 

Option C. Flow cytometry: This test can help classify leukemia subtypes by analyzing cell surface markers but is typically performed after a bone marrow examination to confirm the diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For suspected chloroma in the context of AML, a bone marrow examination is the critical next step to confirm the diagnosis and guide treatment.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1150-1154

choices.text: A- Aldosterone, B- Cortisol, C- Androgen, D- Epinephrine
A- Aldosterone, B- Androgen, C- Cortisol, D- Epinephrine
A- Aldosterone, B- Epinephrine, C- Androgen, D- Cortisol
A- Cortisol, B- Aldosterone, C- Androgen, D- Epinephrine

questions.text: Hormones secreted from A, B, C, D are respectively (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A- Aldosterone, B- Cortisol, C- Androgen, D- Epinephrine

 

The adrenal gland has distinct zones, each responsible for secreting specific hormones:

 

A. Zona Glomerulosa : Secretes mineralocorticoids, primarily aldosterone, which regulates blood pressure and electrolyte balance.

 

B. Zona Fasciculata : Secretes glucocorticoids, primarily cortisol, which regulates metabolism and immune response.

 

C. Zona Reticularis : Secretes androgens, which are precursors to sex hormones.

 

D. Adrenal Medulla : Secretes catecholamines, mainly epinephrine and norepinephrine, which are involved in the fight-or-flight response.

 

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The adrenal gland's zones and their respective hormones are:

 

  • Zona Glomerulosa: Aldosterone
  • Zona Fasciculata: Cortisol
  • Zona Reticularis: Androgens
  • Adrenal Medulla: Epinephrine

questions.text: A statistician is examining the scores of a recent standardized test to assess the variability in student performance. She is particularly interested in understanding the extent of score dispersion from the lowest to the highest mark achieved. Which statistical measure should she use to directly determine this? [INICET NOV 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Range

 

  • Range is expressed as minimum - maximum (or maximum – minimum) values in a given set of data.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Variance: It is given as square of standard deviation (Deviation of each value from the standard value).

 

Option B. Coefficient of variation (COV): It is a measure used to compare relative variability.

 

Option D. Interquartile range: Quartiles divide the distribution into 4 equal groups. The difference between Q1 and Q3 gives the interquartile range.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The range directly measures the extent of score dispersion from the lowest to the highest value in a dataset.

choices.text: Bicarbonate in the intracellular compartment
Calcium in the extracellular compartment

questions.text: Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium is mainly due to? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Intracellular proteins

 

Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium is mainly due to intracellular proteins.

 

The Gibbs-Donnan effect describes the unequal distribution of Diffusible charged ions on either side of a semipermeable membrane which occurs in the presence of impermeant charged ions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phosphate: While phosphate ions are present in both intracellular and extracellular compartments, they are not the primary cause of the Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium. Their concentrations do not significantly contribute to the electrochemical gradient and osmotic balance in the same way as intracellular proteins do.

 

Option B. Bicarbonate in the intracellular compartment: Bicarbonate ions are crucial for maintaining acid-base balance, but they are not the main factor in establishing the Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium. Their movement across membranes is more related to pH regulation rather than creating an electrochemical gradient due to impermeant ions.

 

Option C. Calcium in the extracellular compartment: Calcium ions are essential for various cellular functions, including muscle contraction and neurotransmission, but they do not play a primary role in the Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium. Their concentration differences across membranes are tightly regulated by channels and pumps, rather than by the presence of impermeant ions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

At Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium,

 

  • On each side of the membrane, each solution will be electrically neutral
  • The product of diffusible ions on one side of the membrane will be equal to the product of diffusible ions on the other side of the membrane
  • The electrochemical gradients produced by unequal distribution of charged ions produces a transmembrane potential difference which can be calculated using the Nernst equation
  • The presence of impermeant ions on one side of the membrane creates an osmotic diffusion gradient attracting water into that compartment.

 

Intracellular proteins are negatively charged non-permeable ions, then distribution of other permeable ions is affected in a predictable way (Donnan Effect) so that at equilibrium their concentration ratios are equal.

questions.text: Which structures pass between superior and middle constrictor?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IX nerve (Glossopharyngeal Nerve)

 

The pharyngeal constrictor muscles are organized into three main parts: the superior, middle, and inferior constrictors. Each of these muscles plays a crucial role in the mechanics of swallowing and speech.

 

The glossopharyngeal nerve passes between the superior and middle constrictor muscles. This is a key anatomical relationship to remember as it is crucial for the nerve supply to the pharynx.

Other Options:

 

Option A. Eustachian Tube: Passes through the sinus of Morgagni, not between the superior and middle constrictors.

 

Option C. Superior Laryngeal Nerve: Passes between the middle and inferior constrictors, not the superior and middle constrictors.

 

Option D. Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve: Passes between the inferior constrictor and the esophagus, not between the superior and middle constrictors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The IX nerve (Glossopharyngeal nerve) and the stylopharyngeus muscle pass between the superior and middle constrictor muscles of the pharynx.

choices.text: Factor VII
Factor V
Factor XII
