questions.text: Which of the following clotting factor deficiency will not affect clotting in vivo? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Factor XII

 

Factor XII, also known as Hageman factor, is part of the intrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade. Although Factor XII is essential in the laboratory-based tests for clotting, such as the activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT), its deficiency does not result in a bleeding tendency in vivo.

 

  • In vivo, tissue factor (TF) plays the central role in initiating the coagulation process, which primarily involves the extrinsic pathway. The extrinsic pathway is triggered by exposure of TF to the blood, which leads to the activation of Factor VII, and subsequently, the common pathway, ultimately forming a clot.
  • Factor XII deficiency does not cause bleeding in vivo because it is not required for the tissue factor pathway, which is the primary pathway for initiating coagulation in the body. In fact, people with Factor XII deficiency do not typically experience abnormal bleeding, despite having prolonged aPTT in laboratory tests.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Factor VII: Essential for the extrinsic pathway; deficiency leads to bleeding disorders.

 

Option B. Factor V: Part of the common pathway; deficiency leads to bleeding disorders.

 

Option D. Factor IX: Essential for the intrinsic pathway; deficiency causes Hemophilia B, a bleeding disorder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Factor XII deficiency will not affect the clotting in vivo. In vivo, tissue factor is the major initiator of coagulation. It is amplified by feedback loops involving thrombin.

questions.text: Which amino acid is not used for synthesis of hormones?(INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Glycine

 

Glycine is an amino acid that does not directly participate in the synthesis of hormones. While glycine is an important amino acid involved in many biological processes, including the synthesis of proteins, it is not a precursor for hormone synthesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tyrosine: Tyrosine is a precursor for the synthesis of several important hormones, including thyroid hormones (thyroxine and triiodothyronine), catecholamines (epinephrine, norepinephrine, and dopamine), and melanin.

 

Option B. Phenylalanine: Phenylalanine is converted into tyrosine in the body and, as a result, indirectly contributes to hormone synthesis. Tyrosine, derived from phenylalanine, is then used for the synthesis of various hormones.

 

Option C. Tryptophan: Tryptophan is an essential amino acid that serves as a precursor for the synthesis of serotonin and melatonin, both of which are important hormones involved in regulating mood, sleep, and other physiological processes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tyrosine, phenylalanine, and tryptophan are all aromatic amino acids that serve as building blocks for the synthesis of various hormones.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male patient underwent hernia surgery and complained of a loss of sensations over the root of his penis during his postoperative recovery. The patient reported no prior history of genital trauma or surgery. Which of the following nerves would you suspect to be the cause of the patient's loss of sensation? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ilioinguinal nerve

 

The ilioinguinal nerve is the most likely nerve to be implicated in this scenario. It provides sensation to the skin over the root of the penis and adjacent part of the scrotum, and can be injured during inguinal hernia repair surgery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The Iliohypogastric nerve: The Iliohypogastric nerve carries sensory supply from the suprapubic area. Injury to this nerve rarely causes sensory disturbances in the right iliac fossa due to the rich nerve supply from other sources. However, severing this nerve above the anterior superior iliac spine can lead to weakened posterior wall of the inguinal canal, resulting in a direct inguinal hernia. Injury to this nerve can also occur following appendicectomy.

 

Option C. The genitofemoral nerve: The genitofemoral nerve has a genital branch that provides sensation to the scrotum in males and mons pubis and labia majora in females. Injury to the genital branch can cause loss of sensation in these areas.

 

The femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve causes hypoesthesia over the anterior thigh below the inguinal ligament, but this is not relevant to the patient's symptoms.

 

Option D. The medial cutaneous nerve of the thigh: The medial cutaneous nerve of the thigh a sensory branch of the femoral nerve that supplies sensation to the anterior-medial aspect of the thigh and knee. Injury to this nerve can lead to loss of sensation in these areas, but is not related to the patient's loss of sensation in the root of the penis.

choices.text: Sporothrix schencki
Corynebacterium minutissimum
Nocardia brasiliensis

questions.text: On inoculation in the skin, all of the following organisms can lead to dermal, subcutaneous, and lymphatic involvement except? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Corynebacterium minutissimum

 

Corynebacterium minutissimum causes a localized infection of the stratum corneum called erythrasma and does not involve the dermal, subcutaneous, or lymphatic tissues.

 

Details of Erythrasma:

 

  • Pathogen: Corynebacterium minutissimum
  • Common Sites: Axillae, groin, and other intertriginous areas
  • Clinical Features: Presents as well-demarcated, reddish-brown patches that can be mistaken for fungal infections.
  • Predisposing Factors: More common in diabetics and elderly individuals.
  • Diagnosis: Can be confirmed with Wood's lamp examination (coral-red fluorescence) and gram staining.
  • Growth Characteristics: This lipophilic corynebacterium grows readily in media containing 20% fetal calf serum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sporothrix schenckii: Causes sporotrichosis, characterized by nodular lymphangitis. The infection can spread via lymphatic channels leading to a linear chain of nodules.

 

Option C. Nocardia brasiliensis: Causes nocardiosis, which can involve skin, subcutaneous tissues, and lymphatics, leading to nodular lymphangitis and abscess formation.

 

Option D. Mycobacterium marinum: Causes a cutaneous infection that can progress along lymphatic channels leading to nodular lymphangitis, commonly seen in fish tank granuloma.

 

Educational objective

 

Corynebacterium minutissimum, the causative agent of erythrasma, is limited to superficial skin infections and does not cause dermal, subcutaneous, or lymphatic involvement.

 

Nodular lymphangitis, the most common causes include:

 

  1. Sporothrix schenckii
  2. Nocardia brasiliensis
  3. Mycobacterium marinum
  4. Leishmania brasiliensis

questions.text: What does the ECG show? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans.  B) P pulmonale

 

The ECG presented shows tall P waves in lead II, which are characteristic of P pulmonale. P pulmonale refers to the presence of abnormally tall P waves in the ECG, usually greater than 2.5 mm in height in lead II. This finding indicates right atrial enlargement, which is commonly associated with pulmonary conditions such as pulmonary hypertension. Right atrial enlargement occurs due to increased pressure or volume overload in the right atrium, often secondary to lung diseases that lead to increased pulmonary artery pressures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Electrical alternans: Electrical alternans is characterized by alternating amplitude or direction of the QRS complexes in the ECG. It is often associated with large pericardial effusions and is not indicated by the tall P waves seen in this ECG.

 

Option C. Ventricular bigeminy: Ventricular bigeminy refers to a rhythm where every normal beat is followed by a premature ventricular contraction (PVC). The ECG would show alternating normal QRS complexes with PVCs, which is not seen here.

 

Option D. Improper calibration: Improper calibration of an ECG machine would result in uniformly abnormal waves across all leads, which does not match the specific tall P waves observed in lead II in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

P pulmonale, indicated by tall P waves greater than 2.5 mm in lead II, signifies right atrial enlargement commonly due to pulmonary hypertension or other pulmonary conditions leading to increased right atrial pressure.

questions.text: The below-given image is characteristically seen in which of the following type of leprosy? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Borderline leprosy (BB Leprosy)

 

The given image shows a case of borderline leprosy, or dimorphous leprosy, as evidenced by the inverted saucer shaped cutaneous lesions on the patient's skin.

 

Key Characteristics of Borderline Leprosy

 

  • Lesions: Borderline leprosy often presents with numerous skin lesions which may be macular (flat), papular (raised), or annular (ring-shaped) with less defined borders compared to tuberculoid leprosy. The lesions can sometimes exhibit an "inverted saucer" appearance, where the center appears slightly depressed.
  • Symmetry: The lesions tend to be asymmetrical.
  • Sensory Loss: These lesions usually show some sensory loss, although not as pronounced as in tuberculoid leprosy.
  • Reactivity: Borderline leprosy is particularly unstable immunologically, prone to reactivations and shifts toward either more or less severe forms, depending on immune changes in the individual.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Borderline Tuberculoid Leprosy: Closer to the tuberculoid pole with fewer, well-defined lesions and significant nerve involvement.

 

Option B. Lepromatous Leprosy: At the opposite pole from tuberculoid leprosy, characterized by numerous lesions including nodules and plaques, with a high bacterial load but minimal sensory loss.

 

Option D. Histoid Leprosy: A rare variant of lepromatous leprosy presenting as nodules and plaques, often occurring in patients who have experienced leprosy treatment or relapse.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Patients with borderline leprosy are at risk for developing reactions like Type 1 (reversal) reactions, which can lead to rapid worsening of lesions and require immediate medical attention.
  • Accurate diagnosis based on clinical presentation, bacterial index, and histopathology is crucial as the treatment duration and regimen may differ based on the type of leprosy. Borderline leprosy is typically treated with multi-drug therapy (MDT), similar to other forms of leprosy.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of Dermatology 9th edition page no 28.3, 28.5, 28.10

choices.text: Acute lymphoblastic leukemia
Chronic lymphocytic leukemia
Acute myeloid leukemia
Chronic myelogenous leukemia

questions.text: The given peripheral smear is associated with which of the following leukemias? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chronic lymphocytic leukemia

 

The peripheral smear findings point toward a diagnosis of chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

 

The blood contains large numbers of small round lymphocytes with scant cytoplasm. Some of these cells are usually disrupted in the process of making smears, producing so-called smudge cells. Lymphocytes are of same size and configuration with a uniform appearance called as "convent-girl" appearance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL): The peripheral smear in ALL typically shows a high number of lymphoblasts, which are larger than normal lymphocytes and have a high nuclear-cytoplasmic ratio. There would be an absence of smudge cells, which are characteristic of CLL.

 

Option C. Acute myeloid leukemia (AML): AML is characterized by the presence of myeloblasts in the peripheral blood smear. These cells are larger, have more cytoplasm, and may contain Auer rods. Again, smudge cells are not a feature of AML.

 

Option D. Chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML): The peripheral smear in CML shows a full spectrum of myeloid cells, from myeloblasts to mature neutrophils, often with an increase in basophils and eosinophils. Smudge cells are not a characteristic finding in CML.

 

Educational Objective:
